urn:contentItem:6FX5-V1F3-S5MG-5172-00000-00Forest fire season started early. Here's how to prepare in N.L.2025-05-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWSForest fire season started early. Here's how to prepare in N.L.

Newfoundland and Labrador is facing an early and busy start to the forest fire season.

It's because of the lack of snow over the winter, says forest services conservation officer Sarah Richards. 

"Spring grass fires are always a huge concern, especially on the Avalon," Richards told CBC News during a wildfire preparedness event held at Bowring Park in St. John's over the weekend.

The provincial forestry department and the St. John's Regional Fire Department (SJRFD) teamed up to host the event on Sunday. 

Richards said they wanted to join forces to help homeowners get ready for the summer, and to promote ways to mitigate risk. 

"Something as simple as taking your quad out for a ride, cigarette butts, all that stuff can ignite fires when [the] forest is that dry," she said.

Campfires and bonfires can be risky, too, at the start of fire season. 

"[People] don't realize how important it is to make sure those fires are put out," Richards said.

"Soak it well, give it a good stir and then soak it again and just make sure they're actually out."

The province's heavy winds can also contribute to the spread of those fires. Richards recommends considering how high the winds are and how dry the grass is before starting a fire. 

As for protecting your home, Richards says the first 30 meters around a property is the main hazard area. 

She said embers in the air could get into the mulch in your yard. She recommends keeping the eavestrough clean, lawns mowed and trees trimmed. 

More tips are available on the Fire Smart Canada website.

Mindfulness

SJRFD fire prevention officer Cara Pardy says it's likely to be a rough year for forest fires.

She says it's important for people to be mindful when starting fires.

"[A] very important thing is to make sure the fire is out before you go to bed for the night, or before you leave to go outside somewhere," Pardy said.

For backyard fires, Pardy recommends having a fire extinguisher, garden hose, or pails of water nearby.

She also recommends that residents keep an eye on the forest fire index, social media and the news for fire bans in their area. 

"The grass is starting to green up now, so we should be safe for a little while until it gets hot and dry, and then things will get more scary again," she said.

urn:contentItem:6GTN-Y063-RRSC-92YP-00000-00Greater Victoria’s apocalyptic sun likely not due to ’80s volcanic ash2025-09-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 29Greater Victoria’s apocalyptic sun likely not due to ’80s volcanic ashChristine Van Reeuwyk

Waking to cars covered in ash and an apocalyptic sun, Greater Victoria residents scoured social media Wednesday (Sept. 17) in search of a source.

What many learned is the ash that blanketed parts of the U.S.when Mount St. Helens erupted in 1980 could be stirring, according to the US Geological Service. However, as the wildfire season continues to burn, the online firesmoke map shows particulates percolating around the eastern portion of Vancouver Island.

The USGS issued an alert midday Tuesday that strong easterly-southeasterly winds in the area of Mt. St. Helens was picking up loose volcanic ash that fell during the eruptions 45 years ago, carrying it west-northwest. The resuspended ash was reported by pilots near the volcano – more than 400 kilometres south of Victoria in Washington state.

“This phenomenon is not the result of recent volcanic activity and occasionally occurs during times of high winds and dry snow-free conditions in the Mount St. Helens area,” the agency said. “Resuspended volcanic ash should be considered hazardous and could be damaging to aircraft and health.”

However, the ash falling in the north is not likely the resurrected ash, the agency told the Victoria News. Photos look more like forest fire ash, a spokesperson said, which is black and water soluble. Mt. St. Helens volcanic ash is extremely fine particles, like baby powder, and light grey.

The agency is still looking into the volcanic ash ongoing forecast.

In the meantime, 125 wildfires are burning in B.C. at the moment, with several more south of the border.

An online mapping tool BlueSky Canada offers smoke and fire weather forecasts produced by the Weather Forecast Research Team at UBC.

It shows a large fire burning due south of Victoria in the Olympic Mountains.

urn:contentItem:6H16-4H33-S0SJ-50H6-00000-00Wildfire seasons in the N.W.T. unlikely to ease off by next century, study finds2025-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWSWildfire seasons in the N.W.T. unlikely to ease off by next century, study finds

The Northwest Territories could see more difficult wildfire seasons ahead - all the way into the next century according to recent research.

One study published last month by researchers from the University of British Columbia and Natural Resources Canada predicts that while the rest of the country will see an increase in burn probability by 2100, the N.W.T.'s rate will remain about the same.

Chris Mulverhill, one of the study's co-authors, said the chance of a wildfire in Yellowknife is already as high as it can get.

"We hopefully don't want to give the impression that Yellowknife [and other northern communities] are going to be spared from intense fire seasons in the future," he wrote in an email. 

However, there are challenges with predicting the future.

Mulverhill said the projections are based on current forest conditions, but climate change in northern areas is expected to cause large changes in the structure, composition, and condition of vegetation.

A unique set of drivers

Meanwhile, a different study published last month by researchers at the University of Toronto states wildfires in the subarctic are driven by different factors than in areas further south. 

The study found that the state of vegetation before fires, the amount of humidity in the soil and wind exposure are some of the most important factors in the subarctic.

"If you have diseased or dead vegetation, that's a source of fuel for the fire," said Kent Moore, one of the co-authors of the study.

"It's a consequence of climate change that the state of the forest is not as healthy as it used to be."

Moore said a lack of rain over summers could dry out vegetation even more and lead to low soil moisture, no matter how much it rains or snows in the spring. 

Up to 40 per cent of the territory has been affected by severe to extreme drought since 2022, according to a recent report from the government of the Northwest Territories.

Local capacity

Danny Masuzumi, the executive director of the K'ahsho Got'ine Foundation Guardians, said the findings of these two studies track with what the K'ahsho Got'ine Foundation Guardians are seeing on the ground, and what they expect of the future. He said he felt it was important to take researchers' projections seriously.

His community mostly saw small wildfires this season. But in 2024, wildfires triggered an evacuation in Fort Good Hope where the foundation's offices are located. Masuzumi said he wants his community to be prepared to face more difficult years.

"We don't want to have another forest fire that puts people's lives in danger," he said. 

His team has been trained for wildfire fighting since 2022, but he said they don't have enough dedicated firefighters to face a future of intense wildfire seasons.  

He said there is a need for a full fire brigade in the area his team is responsible for in the Sahtu region. There is equipment available: the community purchased about $100,000 of firefighting equipment last year. 

"If we, the Guardians, take on this role, it's going to be too overwhelming," he said.

Masuzumi said he understands the N.W.T. fire crews have limited resources, but even small fires can have big impacts on wildlife habitats.

"Whatever forest we have that's not burnt, I feel that maybe we should try and protect those areas as to make sure they don't burn too," he said. 

Masuzumi said he would like leadership and the community in Fort Good Hope to come together and make a plan for fighting wildfires in the future. He said there has been talk of a brigade before, but as far as he knows, the project has been shelved. 

"We have to feel accountable for things like this because nobody else is going to do it for us," he said. "It has to come from the whole community."

urn:contentItem:6GGG-FXM3-RWG6-01S9-00000-00Halifax-area crews are making progress on forest fire near Bayers Lake2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisCHEMICALS INDUSTRY NEWS & NATURAL DISASTERS NEWSHalifax-area crews are making progress on forest fire near Bayers Lake

Nova Scotia's Department of Natural Resources said progress has been made on a wildfire that began in Halifax's Bayers Lake Business Park Tuesday afternoon, but it's still considered out of control.

In an update at 8:27 p.m., DNR estimated the fire - located in the wooded area behind Julius Boulevard and Dugger McNeil Drive behind the Kent Building Supplies store - to be between 25 and 30 hectares.

Twelve DNR firefighters will be at the site overnight Tuesday. The update said one DNR helicopter is dropping water and three planes that were sent in from New Brunswick to help were returning home - but could come back if needed. 

In an update at 9:40 p.m. AT, the Halifax Regional Municipality said most Halifax Regional Fire and Emergency firefighters have departed the scene and are expected to come back Wednesday morning "to assess the state of the fire and resume firefighting efforts, as needed." Two engines and crews will remain in the area overnight to support DNR.

Residents are being asked to avoid unnecessary travel to the Bayers Lake area "until advised otherwise, as reducing traffic congestion will help emergency crews respond to the fire."

Halifax Regional Fire and Emergency deputy chief Dave Meldrum told CBC News the call for the fire came in around 2:30 p.m. AT.

Halifax Fire had 13 trucks at the scene, about 10 kilometres west of downtown Halifax.

Four air tankers from New Brunswick arrived and actively dropped water on the fire.

6 p.m. news update on Bayers Lake fire:
 

All businesses between Kent Building Supplies and Julius Boulevard were evacuated. Other businesses in the area told CBC News they were asked to evacuate as well. 

Overnight street closures

In an update at 7:30 p.m. AT, Halifax police said the following streets would be closed overnight:

No residences had been evacuated, police told CBC News around 4 p.m. Meldrum said there is no current risk to structures.

"Lessening the traffic congestion will help crews respond to the fire and allow those evacuating to leave safely," police told CBC News in an email.

Nova Scotia Health confirmed the Bayers Lake Community Outpatient Centre was evacuated and that the facility's emergency response plans were being activated.  

Poor air quality

Environment Canada and Nova Scotia's Department of Health and Wellness issued a special air quality statement on Tuesday afternoon, saying smoke from the Bayers Lake fire was reducing air quality in the metro Halifax and western Halifax County areas.

People aged 65 and older, pregnant people, infants and young children, people with an existing illness or chronic health condition, and people who work outdoors, are considered higher risk and should avoid strenuous activities outdoors and seek medical attention if experiencing symptoms, the statement said. 

"As smoke levels increase, health risks increase. Limit time outdoors. Consider reducing or rescheduling outdoor sports, activities and events. You may experience mild and common symptoms such as eye, nose and throat irritation, headaches or a mild cough. More serious but less common symptoms include wheezing, chest pains or severe cough."

The statement recommended people keep doors and windows closed when indoors.

"When there is an extreme heat event occurring with poor air quality, prioritize keeping cool," the statement said.

Veronica MacIsaac was out for lunch at Jack Astor's in Bayers Lake when a friend spotted the smoke.

"Behind the side of Bayers Lake where the Giant Tiger would be, there was just a huge big cloud of smoke and it very quickly was spreading through the restaurant," MacIsaac told CBC News.

"And people were quickly paying their bills and trying to get out of there."

MacIsaac said one of the staff at the restaurant drove out to see what was happening and noted some areas were being evacuated and roads were closing.

"We got in an Uber and tried to get out of there, but traffic was already starting to get pretty congested," she said.

Smoke from the fire could be seen across Halifax on Tuesday afternoon.

urn:contentItem:6GY2-SCP3-RS81-C11X-00000-00Small Point-Adam's Cove-Blackhead-Broad Cove defers election as fire cleanup continues2025-10-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisSmall Point-Adam's Cove-Blackhead-Broad Cove defers election as fire cleanup continues

As residents of most municipalities in Newfoundland and Labrador went to the polls on Thursday night, those along Conception Bay's north shore gathered to talk about getting their lives back on track.

The municipality of Small Point-Adam's Cove-Blackhead-Broad Cove opted to defer its election for six months, as it deals with the cleanup from a wildfire that destroyed more than 30 homes within its municipal boundaries.

Deputy Mayor Mark Ploughman said the decision came after a suggestion from the provincial government to have continuity for residents at such a turbulent time.

"The councillors are absolutely committed to staying on," Ploughman told CBC Radio's St. John's Morning Show. "They're very committed to the town and supporting the residents through all of this."

More than 70 people turned up for the meeting on Thursday night, with another 30 watching online. The biggest concern was security, as the region dealt with looting during its three-week evacuation in August, and a rise in break-ins since residents have returned home.

"The crime rates have spiked a little bit here," Ploughman said. "People on the heels of the wildfire are not feeling very safe."

Ploughman said the loss of institutions was another big topic. The Adam's Cove School, a heritage building, burned in the fire. So did Cabot Academy, a K-6 school in nearby Western Bay.

The fire ravaged about 200 homes and businesses in total, leaving a path of destruction from just beyond Perry's Cove all the way to Northern Bay. Police are investigating the Aug. 3 fire, along with several previous fires, as suspected arsons.

As of Friday morning, the province's active forest fire dashboard was finally clear, with the Conception Bay North fire considered fully extinguished.

The municipality of Small Point-Adam's Cove-Blackhead-Broad Cove is still operating a welcome centre, dishing out about 100 meals per day. The demand for bottled water is beginning to dwindle, Ploughman said, as the town's water supply has been given the all-clear and well-water testing is beginning to wrap up.

Ploughman said the municipality has begun forming working groups and steering committees aimed at identifying issues and matching them with potential funding streams to help get residents back on their feet.

The next election for the area will be held in April.

urn:contentItem:6GH3-8X83-RWY6-F2SH-00000-00Critics of forest fire restrictions can't see the truth for the burning trees2025-08-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisOPINION/CONTRIBUTORSPg. 1Critics of forest fire restrictions can't see the truth for the burning treesSharan Kaur, Contributor

Wildfires are currently raging across Canada, from the Pacific shores of Vancouver Island to the eastern expanses of Newfoundland, Nova Scotia and New Brunswick. So stark is the threat in Atlantic Canada that governments there have temporarily banned many outdoor activities due to the heightened risk - prompting some to claim this represents an encroachment on Canadians' freedom.

But with parched forests and conditions ripe for disaster, the recent bans on outdoor leisure activities in Nova Scotia and New Brunswick are not government overreach; they are essential measures to safeguard lives and protect vital ecosystems.

Alarmingly, amid this crisis, some "freedom fighters" and voices from the chattering class, including Shopify CEO Tobi Lütke, argue that these restrictions infringe on personal liberties. But the reality is clear: a single spark, whether from an ATV, a vehicle, or a careless cigarette butt can set ablaze a forest ready to ignite. While frustrations are understandable, the outrage is nonsensical and comes from a place of ignorance.

Currently, over 700 active wildfires are burning across Canada, underscoring the urgency of this national crisis. This fire season has already consumed an astonishing 16.5 million hectares of forest, more than double the previous record and nearly seven times the historical average. The scale of destruction this year alone has necessitated widespread evacuations, including the displacement of 900 individuals in Newfoundland due to three uncontrolled fires. In Atlantic Canada, the national fire threat level remains at its highest, with exceptionally dry conditions persisting.

Climate change is profoundly exacerbating wildfire risks. Canada is warming twice as fast as the global average, making fires bigger, hotter, and more frequent. In 2023, climate change more than doubled the likelihood of extreme fire weather conditions in Eastern Canada. Consequently, fire seasons are starting earlier, lasting longer, and becoming increasingly difficult to contain, with more lighting strikes increasing the risk of new ignitions.

As Premier Tim Houston announces essential restrictions on activities such as hiking, fishing, and off-roading, backlash from those who see these measures as infringements on freedom points to a troubling misunderstanding of wildfire dynamics. Conditions are so dire that the federal government has mobilized the armed forces and Coast Guard to assist in firefighting efforts across the country. The precarious state of our forests demands immediate attention, as just one spark can trigger catastrophic blazes that engulf entire landscapes and communities.

The economic implications of uncontrolled wildfires are also staggering. Increased insurance rates and recovery costs burden communities long after the flames dissipate. According to the Canadian Climate Institute, since the 1970s the cost of wildfire protection has risen by approximately $150 million per decade, with costs exceeding $1 billion in six of the last ten years. In 2023 alone, the health impacts from wildfire smoke were estimated to cost Ontario over $1.2 billion in a single week due to increased hospital visits and health emergencies, which underscores the broader societal costs of fires.

When government officials take decisive action to protect both the environment and public safety, it is not a matter of control, but rather a matter of survival. As wildfires escalate across Canada, the need for urgent intervention is clear. These measures, including bans on outdoor activities during peak fire risk, are not mere restrictions; they are essential for safeguarding human lives and preserving our fragile ecosystems.

In the midst of rising chatter about "personal freedom," we must confront a painful truth: our individual rights must at times yield to the greater good.

The bans imposed are necessary steps to protect our communities and the natural world we all rely on. Ignoring the science behind wildfires, along with the very real threats they pose, not only endangers lives but also undermines collective public safety.

After all, this isn't just about your personal liberties; it's about protecting the well-being of everyone around you and the environment we all share. It is at times like these that we need to adhere a couple of simple but true ideas: prioritize collective safety over individual whims, and recognize that in times of crisis, our responsibilities to one another should always come first.

urn:contentItem:6GXK-KW03-RRRP-C41D-00000-00Aviation service firm gains lift2025-10-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSAviation service firm gains liftSandi Krasowski, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Chronicle-Journal

Wisk Air Helicopters has been selected as Northwestern Ontario's newest authorized Garmin Avionics dealer. Mark Wiskemann, Wisk Air president and chief executive officer, said being an authorized Garmin Avionics dealer is a major step forward in aircraft modernization for the wider aviation community in Northwestern Ontario while providing a new service and support hub for commercial and private operators. Wiskemann credits the success of the company to its avionics work placement initiative, which is supported by the Northern Ontario Heritage Fund Corporation (NOHFC). Students are offered hands-on workplace training and experience for avionics at Wisk Air and are now graduating and working full-time at the company.

"We now have a highly trained team in place with the expertise and capacity to work both on our fleet and with various commercial operators in the North who require these services," he said. MPP Kevin Holland said the province's contribution is applied through the NOHFC internship program. "To be able to provide the company with those internships, the money to bring in those internships has been key to their progress," said Holland, adding that without that support, they would have trouble recruiting and retaining people from the programs to stay and work in Ontario. "We're facing labour shortages all around the world. And it's not restricted to Northern Ontario or even Ontario. Anything that we can do to make sure that we're training the workers that are needed in the north is what our government is focused on through our skills development fund." With 11 helicopters and 65 employees, Wisk Air continues to grow while serving as firefighting, power line building, search and rescue, forest fire suppression and mining support, particularly in the Ring of Fire. Wiskemann said they're on year seven of an environmental study for the road to access the Ring of Fire, which he said is going well. "We also do maintenance, we provide overhaul services for other airplanes and now we do avionics," he said. "With Garmin's licensing, we can provide Garmin privileges to all the folks in the aviation market." He called aviation an evolving industry, which requires many upgrades and advantages that come from new avionics. With new technology and regulations coming, Richard Sheppard, Wisk Air Helicopter's avionics manager, said they are constantly upgrading. "We started in 2023 with a single avionics technician, and demand ramped up significantly," said Sheppard. "NOHFC helped us navigate this challenge by investing in people as well as technology." He added that in the last 16 months, the Wisk Air avionics team has updated and maintained avionics for dozens of commercial operators and private aircraft owners in Northwestern Ontario, including North Star Air, Wilderness North, Air Bravo, Thunder Airlines, KBM Resource Group and Confederation College's fleet of Cessna 172 flight training aircraft. The combination of leading-edge Garmin technology and specialized, local avionics expertise gives both rotary and fixed-wing operators expanded access to modern systems installed and supported by local avionics experts.

urn:contentItem:6GGF-C003-RRPY-C2C8-00000-00Crews battling 'significant' wildfires2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisLOCAL / NEWSPg. A1Crews battling 'significant' wildfiresResidents, visitors are urged to avoid the Burnt River areaTodd Vandonk Reporter

Roughly 27 hectares continues to burn in the Burnt River area.

According to the City of Kawartha Lakes, Kawartha Lakes Fire Rescue Service (KLFRS) has been working to contain the "significant" forest fire since Friday.

"The ice storm brought down a lot of trees and there's a lot brush on the ground, so it makes it hard to get at," said City of Kawartha Lakes mayor Doug Elmslie. "It is all fuel for the fire, so it is a difficult situation."

Elmslie said the Ministry of Natural Resources (MNR) is leading the efforts because the City of Kawartha Lakes doesn't have the resources.

On Sunday afternoon, aerial water support - including water bombers - targeted the most active fire zones. Tanker trucks are drawing water from local lakes to supplement firefighting efforts on the ground.

"They seem to be making some headway, but with the dryness and the breeze it is hit and miss," Elmslie added.

"It is would be nice if we got three days of steady rain."

On Monday, MNR was deploying seven fire crews to help contain the fire.

"I think their plan for today (Monday) is to try and attack it on the ground," explained Elmslie.

Elmslie said there's no plan for evacuation at this time because there's no appreciable community in that area.

"It is pretty remote," he explained. "It is the middle of the forest and it is not threatening residences."

He said safety remains the highest priority for all crews on scene.

"The good thing is, no one has been hurt," he added.

Residents and visitors are urged to avoid the Burnt River area. As of Monday morning, a road closure remains in effect on County Road 49 between County Road 121 and Bury's Green until further notice.

A total fire ban remains is in effect across the City of Kawartha Lakes.

Meanwhile, other forest fires are burning in the Haliburton Fire Management Area.

According to the Ministry of Natural Resources' Forest Fire Info Map on Monday, the following fires are burning:

HAL019: A 27-hectare area north of Bobcaygeon, just southeast of Burnt River near County Road 121 and Highway 49. The ministry is reporting that this first began on Saturday, Aug. 9 around 5 p.m. As of Sunday morning it was listed as "not under control."

HAL016: A 4.5-hectare area south of Head Lake, west of Norland, off County Road 45. This fire began on Aug. 8 and is listed as "under control."

HAL017: A 1.6-hectare section just north of Head Lake in Queen Elizabeth II Wildlands. This fire began on Aug. 8. It is listed as 'under control.".

HAL018: An 11-hectare area in the County of Hastings, north of Marmora and east of Apsley. This fire began on Aug. 9 and is listed as "not under control."

For up to date forest fire information, visit kawarthalakes.ca or the MNR website.

urn:contentItem:6GHR-3BS3-RRWV-K0Y6-00000-00Bancroft and North Hastings under total fire ban2025-08-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSBancroft and North Hastings under total fire banMichael Riley, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterThe Bancroft Times

The Town of Bancroft and all of North Hastings are under a total fire ban as of Aug. 6, according to the Bancroft fire department website and social media feeds due to the extremely hot, dry conditions. Limerick Fire Chief Greg Maxwell, Limerick Mayor Kim Carson, Bancroft Mayor Paul Jenkins and Bancroft Fire Chief Pat Hoover comment on this total fire ban to The Bancroft Times. For any further questions or information, contact the Bancroft Fire Department at 613-332-2442 or the local fire department in whatever North Hastings municipality you reside.  

According to the media release on the ban, there will be no open-air fires or burning of any kind allowed during this total fire ban including; campfires, burn barrels, wood or charcoal burning barbecues or outdoor stoves, or fireworks and flying lanterns. However, CSA approved gas cooking appliances may be used for cooking at this time. 

The ban will be fully enforced in all of North Hastings, which includes the Town of Bancroft, Faraday, Carlow Mayo, Wollaston, Hastings Highlands, Limerick and Tudor and Cashel. Any violators will face applicable fines and charges, and any person deemed liable for a fire during this ban will face any and all costs incurred as a result of the fire department’s response and action taken to put out the fire. No burn permits will be issued during this ban and it will remain in effect until significant rainfall occurs a review by the fire department is conducted. The ban will only be lifted by the participating fire departments. 

Maxwell told The Bancroft Times that he just wants people to know that it’s serious when they put out a fire ban. 

“Owners that rent out their properties need to make sure renters know about the fire ban and all the rules. We will not be lifting the fire ban until we get a substantial amount of rain and everything starts turning green again,” he says.

Carson says they have been seeing a significant amount of dry, hot weather and little to no rain for an extended period of time. 

“This creates a high risk for fire. Putting a fire ban in place is asking the public to be aware: no fires, fireworks, or open barbecues to reduce the risk of a fire starting,” she says. 

Jenkins says that fire ban in an absolute necessity given the extremely low rainfall and high temperatures over the last several weeks. 

“Several wildfires are currently burning in the Kawartha/Haliburton and Coe Hill areas highlighting the severity of the situation. I expect the ban to remain in effect until the weather pattern changes and we start to receive significant rainfall,” he says. 

 

Hoover told The Bancroft Times that our region is very dry and the fire index has listed us in the “extreme” category. He says the fire ban will remain in effect until we get significant rainfall to reduce the fire hazard index. He says that long range weather forecast isn’t showing very much.

“Please follow the burning ban to keep our region safe from a forest fire. Your local fire dept only has so much staff and resources that a wildfire may require MNRF support and could cost the municipality financially.  If you do start a forest fire you could be charged under the Forest Fire Prevention Act and held accountable for the extinguishing costs which could be very costly,” he says. “Continue to monitor your local Fire Service social media, the municipal websites and road side signage for changes and updates.”

urn:contentItem:6GFT-FWN3-RTXC-X2PB-00000-00Wildfire season has burned area size of N.B.2025-08-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A12Wildfire season has burned area size of N.B.Jordan Omstead The Canadian Press

Canada's 2025 wildfire season is now the second-worst on record. The latest figures posted by the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre suggest the fires have torn through 72,000 square kilometres, an area roughly the size of New Brunswick.

That surpasses the next worst season in 1989 and is about half the area burned during the record-setting 2023 season, according to a federal database of wildfire seasons dating back to 1972.

Climate change, driven by the burning of fossil fuels, has made Canada's fire season longer and more intense, scientists say. The last three fire seasons are all in the 10 worst on record.

This season has displaced thousands of people and stifled communities across Canada with wildfire smoke. Manitoba and Saskatchewan account for more than half the area burned so far, but British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario are also well above their 25-year averages.

This season has put a strain on Canada's firefighting resources. The country has been at its highest preparedness level since late May, relying on international help to tackle the fires.

There were 446 international firefighters in Canada as of Friday, said Alexandria Jones, a spokesperson for the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre.

This season has officials exploring partnerships with countries whose fire season doesn't so closely overlap with Canada's, unlike the United States, Jones said. More firefighters are coming from Chile, Costa Rica and Mexico this year than in years past.

In all, about 1,400 international firefighters have helped fight Canadian fires so far this year.

The Canadian Press

urn:contentItem:6H6D-NXT3-RSJ3-62GP-00000-00West Fraser to close 100 Mile sawmill2025-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisFRONTPg. 1-2West Fraser to close 100 Mile sawmillPatrick Davies

West Fraser - 100 Mile Lumber will be closing its doors by the end of 2025.

On Thursday, Nov. 6, West Fraser Timber Company announced that it will be permanently closing both its 100 Mile House lumber mill and its Augusta, Georgia lumber mill following an orderly wind-down over the next two months. In its release, West Fraser cited timber supply challenges and current soft lumber markets as reasons behind these decisions.

“The 100 Mile House lumber mill is no longer able to reliably access an adequate volume of economically viable timber. Challenging softwood lumber demand, higher duties and additional tariffs have compounded this situation,” West Fraser stated. “The mill closure will impact approximately 165 employees at the site and reduce West Fraser’s capacity by 160 million board feet.”

West Fraser said it plans to “mitigate the impact” on affected employees by providing work opportunities at other company operations, where available. In the Cariboo, the closest West Fraser Sawmill is located an hour north in Williams Lake.

This news comes six years after West Fraser shuttered its Chasm Sawmill between 70 Mile House and Clinton, and five years almost to the day since Norbord announced the permanent closure of its sawmill in 100 Mile House. West Fraser - 100 Mile Lumber was the last major mill left standing in the area.

“The closure of these mills better positions West Fraser to compete in this challenging environment,” West Fraser said. “The Company expects to record restructuring and impairment charges in the fourth quarter of 2025 associated with this announcement and the factors outlined herein.”

District of 100 Mile House Mayor Maureen Pinkney said that the closure is very unfortunate for all the local workers who work for West Fraser. Pinkney estimated the closure will impact a further 500 jobs when looking at the whole picture.

“When you lose those good-paying jobs, it affects everything,” Pinkney said. “There’s no good time of the year for this to happen, but just before Christmas is even harder. Our retail stores rely on this expanded business period of Christmas to weather the storm for January, February and March. They’re not going to have that cushion.”

Cariboo-Chilcotin MLA Lorne Doerkson agreed with Pinkney that this closure will impact far more than 165 individuals. He described the news as devastating and called it a “dark day” for the economy of the South Cariboo.

“West Fraser has been operating that mill for a number of years, and to find out abruptly, a month and a half away from Christmas, that the mill is going to be closed permanently is devastating, it really is devastating,” Doerkson remarked. “I know the industry is struggling, and I know the tariffs have been devastating, no question about that. There are a lot of challenges this industry has been facing, from the loss of timber through forest fire, to the pine beetle (infestation). We’ve got what I call a permanent crisis in this province. I think this has all had a cumulative effect and we’re seeing it today in 100 Mile House.”

Doerkson said that his understanding is that 100 Mile Lumber will continue to mill the remaining logs it has and close down once it is all milled. He added that he’s been told it’s likely the closure will occur in December once timber runs out.

Meanwhile, CaribooPrince George member of parliament Todd Doherty said it is shattering to think of the 165 families now facing uncertainty. Doherty said that since 2015, close to a dozen mills have been closed throughout his riding. Over the last several years, he said he has brought up this reality several times in Ottawa, but to seemingly no avail.

“The fact we’ve gone 11 years without a softwood lumber agreement (with the United States) and that forestry gets nowhere near the same attention steel, aluminium and other industries receive, it’s absolutely staggering,” Doherty said.

Doherty explained Canada’s previous softwood lumber agreement expired at the end of 2014, and Stephen Harper’s Conservagovernment negotiated a one-year grace period to give the next government time to get the job done. He said that throughout his tenure, Liberal Prime Minister Justin Trudeau never made it a priority.

As the Conservative Party’s chair of the softwood lumber caucus, Doherty said he’s railed against the country’s biggest softwood lumber producers who look to divest themselves of their Canadian operations and invest in the United States instead. At one time, Doherty noted BC was the largest producer of forestry products in the country, but added the industry has been devastated by both provincial and federal policies.

“One of the biggest things I’m hearing is they’re blaming it on the Trump administration and what’s going on there. I’m sure there’s some percentage of blame on that, but let’s be real. This has been happening for years and years, well before Donald Trump was ever president,” Doherty said. “To me, the blame lies squarely on our provincial government and federal government. They need to do something for our producers, families and communities that depend on our forestry dollars to get back to what we do best.”

Long term, Pinkney said that this closure will impact the tax assessment of the area. She noted they saw a similar decrease in assessment after the Ainsworth OSB plant shut down. Every loss means less and less infrastructure for 100 Mile House going forward.

Pinkney expressed frustration with the management of the forestry sector by the B.C. provincial government over the last several years. She noted that since 2017, there have been dozens of mill closures across the province.

“This is a renewable resource that never should have been managed this way, but when is it going to stop?” Pinkney asked. “I believe (the provincial government) has mismanaged the way the allowable cuts are, the way licenses are. There have been so many things wrong for so long.”

While Pinkney acknowledged that the new Minister of Forests, Ravi Parmar, is proactive and seems to have some great new ideas, it ended up being too little too late for 100 Mile House. She said this closure represents the end of an era for 100 Mile House.

“This town was built on forestry. We were a lumber company. Back in the day, there were small mills out in the bush when they used to go to the trees, and then they started bringing the trees to the mill,” Pinkney remarked. “We were 100 per cent a forest town, but we are no longer a forest town. That is huge, it’s been there since the beginning of our community.”

Going forward, Pinkney said she and her council will continue to try to bring new industries to 100 Mile House to help bring more jobs to the community.

On Friday, Nov. 7, the district put out a release expressing its profound disappointment at the news. The district wrote that the closure will have deep impacts on the community, meaning difficult times for the forestry workers, their families, local businesses, schools, support industries, the district, and many others.

“The job loss impacts will be immediate, and other impacts may take more time to surface,” wrote the district in the press release. The release also adds that history has proven that an industry closure is a crisis for the whole community.

The district echoed Pinkney’s pledge to advance and support the many economic opportunities within the District of 100 Mile House. They also highlighted several of the area’s strengths.

“Commercial activity is strong, housing is still affordable, people are relocating to the region, we have a busy highway corridor and visitor economy, and several large projects are in progress,” the release noted. “Council and staff will also be looking for ways to maintain municipal infrastructure and local government operations in what will surely result in a reduced tax rate.”

Pinkney added in the release that 100 Mile had been through mill closures before, as well as difficult economic times and has come out stronger in the end.

“Our community has an amazing network of support agencies and a willingness to work together to support impacted workers and families,” Pinkney is quoted in the release. The release says that Pinkney is encouraging residents to pull together, support one another, and focus on getting through the challenge together.

For his part, Doerkson also pledged to do what he can to support those losing their jobs transition into the future. He noted he’s already had conversations with West Fraser about supporting their employees and Parmar about potential government support. Doerkson said he doesn’t know what that will look like exactly, but plans to share more with the community when he does.

“I do know they’re going to involve the Minister of Jobs in this,” Doerkson said. “I think it’s probably too early to know what those next steps will look like, but I also think it’s wrong to suggest there are just 165 people affected by this. This is going to be a devastating blow to the economy of the entire South Cariboo.”

With Files from Misha Mustaqeem.

urn:contentItem:6GFK-GH93-RRS5-Y2NS-00000-00National agency needed to fight forest fires: chiefs2025-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisCANADA / WORLDPg. A7National agency needed to fight forest fires: chiefsThe Canadian Press

The Canadian Association of Fire Chiefs says it's time for Ottawa to stop studying the idea of a national forest fire co-ordination agency and take action.

The organization's president wants the federal government to take inspiration from the U.S. Fire Administration to establish a similar office in Canada.

The U.S. office is part of Federal Emergency Management Agency, or FEMA, but Ken McMullen says a Canadian version could be simpler and less costly.

He said the proposed fire administration office, which could be staffed by one or two people, would ensure that personnel and equipment are appropriately dispersed across the country in the event of wildfires.

It would also allow security and fire services to have a seat at the table when relevant policies are being discussed.

The Canadian government has been studying the possibility of creating a national disaster response or co-ordination agency ever since the record-breaking forest fire season in the summer of 2023, and McMullen said it's time to start making decisions.

This year could also go down in history as one of the worst in terms of fires.

"We will call it whatever they want us to call it," McMullen said of the proposed office. "We just need it to start.''

He said the information needed to create an agency is already available .

"We just have to get moving and make decisions," said McMullen, who is also fire chief in Red Deer, Alta.

He believes the April federal election and the arrival of a new prime minister have caused delays. McMullen hopes the issue will move forward this fall when Parliament resumes.

urn:contentItem:6GBT-S6P3-RRV9-V0PR-00000-00Air quality warnings, statements over forest fire smoke persist across much of the Northwest2025-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSAir quality warnings, statements over forest fire smoke persist across much of the NorthwestMatt Prokopchuk, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterTBnewswatch.com

NESKANTAGA — Environment Canada says air quality continues to deteriorate across much of the far north and alerts are also in place for many areas east of Thunder Bay.

Wildfire smoke from numerous forest fires in Northwestern Ontario and on the Prairies caused the weather office to issue new air quality warnings and special statements Friday morning.

The more serious warnings extend across much of the far north, from just north of Red Lake to south of Fort Severn, and from the Manitoba border east past Webequie, Neskantaga and Marten Falls.

The special air quality statement is in effect from Armstrong, north of Thunder Bay, and running east just inland from the North Shore, including communities like Greenstone, Manitouwadge, Hornepayne and White River.

“We're seeing heavy concentrations of particulate matter stemming from all the wildfire activity that's still ongoing,” said Steven Flisfeder, a meteorologist with Environment Canada.

“So, (a) pretty far expanding area that's currently under an air quality warning where the concentrations are much higher from the smoke.”

Areas affected by the air quality statement are “still seeing very high concentrations of smoke near the surface, reducing air quality,” he said.

“Not as significantly as in the far north, but still a big area of concern in terms of air quality and, general health as a result.”

As for how the smoke will behave heading into the weekend, Flisfeder said, currently, it’s hard to forecast, given what predictive modelling is showing.

“It could be a situation where these statements, in particular, they may be dropped as we see concentrations get reduced over time, but you can also expect it to be reissued as things evolve over the weekend.”

Flisfeder said the weather office uses data that shows expected changes to weather information, fire behaviour and air pollution along with information from real-time data stations and compares them. “If those are not in alignment with each other, that's when we have less confidence in the model output.”

“The model guidance is doing a pretty poor job of capturing how bad things are currently, so we don't have a lot of confidence in how much it will clear up, unfortunately,” he added.

Environment Canada said people, including those 65 and older, as well as infants and children, people who are pregnant, those who have a chronic health condition and those who work outdoors should reduce or reschedule strenuous outdoor activities and, if symptoms develop, seek medical attention.

People should also keep windows and doors closed as much as possible and take other precautions —like using air filters in ventilation systems and/or portable air cleaners — to mitigate compromising indoor air quality.

“It's really important for people to stay as up to date with their forecasts and alerts just so that they have the best information possible,” Flisfeder said.

urn:contentItem:6H0C-9HF3-RRR3-K050-00000-00Post offices of the North Thompson region2025-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisVALLEY VOICESPg. 8Post offices of the North Thompson regionDonna Kibble

I thought would try and put together a little history of the post offices of the area. I grew up outside of Quesnel in a little country store and post office. Mail would arrive in big bags and my parents would get busy sorting. I especially remember Christmas with all the parcels coming and the excitement of friends getting Christmas cards and gifts.

In 1916 James Nelson built the Barriere hotel. There was a store and post office close by (down across from where the museum is now). I think this was the first one in Barriere. In 1938 the store burned down and Archie Gaudreau operated the post office from his home from 1938 to 1940. Evelyn Neil, Maud Loveway and Bernice Roos filled the position until Charence Humphreys became postmaster. In 1944 Humphreys built a store on the south side of the bridge on the east side of the highway (now Downtown Barriere area). By 1947 he and his wife Jean also had the post office there. I believe this later became the R&R store and post office.

Upper Louis Creek valley Blucher Hall in the northern end was named in 1905 by its first postmaster, Donald “Cap” Fraser. Cahilty Post Office – the midsection of the valley was named by its first postmaster John Cahilty in 1905.

Rural mail delivery and pickup was provided to each farm or ranch in the Louis Creek valley that had a mailbox mounted on a post beside the Louis Creek Valley Road. The first rural mailman for this valley was Jim McCarten of Heffley Creek. Jim would bring the valley mail from Heffley Creek post office every Tuesday by horse and wagon when roads were good and horse and sleigh in the winter months. He would stop at mailboxes along the way and also pick up and outgoing mail left in the box. In 1930 the delivery was changed from Tuesday and Wednesday to Thursday and Friday. Dick George and then George Bedard were the rural mailmen after Jim McCarten.

Louis Creek Post office Postmaster J.F. Smith 1894 - various other postmasters until Florence ran it from 1951-to 1965. The rural mail to Squam Bay on Wednesdays was delivered by Charlie Keller out of the Barriere PO. The first trips were by horse and democrat in summer and by sleigh in winter. When roads improved in 1927 Charlie bought a Model T for use in the summer. He delivered the mail for 25 years and then John Dennery took over until he retired in 1970. Then Rob Rutten operated the route. The post office burned during the forest fire of 2003.

Chinook Cove The first post office was established 1910 on the west side of the North Thompson river It closed in 1968. In 1937 residents towards the north of Chinook cove established a post office and was called the Darfield Post Office. The first postmistress was Sarah Robers, then Vera Underwood and Florence Beharrell.

Chu Chua In 1907 a post office was established in the Chu Chua store and George Fennell or his son, Marston, was in charge of its operation until closing in 1967. The stagecoach brought mail as far as Chu Chua and Ed Fortier delivered it to northern communities.

Little Fort In what is now Little Fort, the residents wanted a post office and petitioned the government. It was named Mt. Olie and the east side post office operated by Mrs. A. Genier for two years from 1907 to 1909. The new one opened in 1910 and postmasters were T. Latremouille, Kingscote, Wolsey, Gainer, Hindmarch, Miskelly Mrs. Steven and Mrs. Livingstone. Mrs. Livingston remained in this position for 35 years.

McLure The first post office in the area was established in 1914 and ran by Arthur Connine. It was the Fishtrap Post Office and was closed in 1926. The name McLure was formally established in 1919 when the ferry was put in place. The post office was part of the ferryman’s job, Vavenby In the community of Vavenby, the train station also served as the local post office, tending to the needs of the community, along with being the location of the only telephone for the area at the time, as it was situated in an addition to the house. In 1955 the post office was moved from the ferry house and Mrs. Christison became the postmaster All pictures and information have been taken from our history book, Exploring our Roots

urn:contentItem:6H0C-9HF3-RRR3-K05T-00000-00Post offices of the North Thompson region2025-10-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisVALLEY VOICESPg. 8Post offices of the North Thompson regionDonna Kibble

I thought would try and put together a little history of the post offices of the area. I grew up outside of Quesnel in a little country store and post office. Mail would arrive in big bags and my parents would get busy sorting. I especially remember Christmas with all the parcels coming and the excitement of friends getting Christmas cards and gifts.

In 1916 James Nelson built the Barriere hotel. There was a store and post office close by (down across from where the museum is now). I think this was the first one in Barriere. In 1938 the store burned down and Archie Gaudreau operated the post office from his home from 1938 to 1940. Evelyn Neil, Maud Loveway and Bernice Roos filled the position until Charence Humphreys became postmaster. In 1944 Humphreys built a store on the south side of the bridge on the east side of the highway (now Downtown Barriere area). By 1947 he and his wife Jean also had the post office there. I believe this later became the R&R store and post office.

Upper Louis Creek valley Blucher Hall in the northern end was named in 1905 by its first postmaster, Donald “Cap” Fraser. Cahilty Post Office – the midsection of the valley was named by its first postmaster John Cahilty in 1905.

Rural mail delivery and pickup was provided to each farm or ranch in the Louis Creek valley that had a mailbox mounted on a post beside the Louis Creek Valley Road. The first rural mailman for this valley was Jim McCarten of Heffley Creek. Jim would bring the valley mail from Heffley Creek post office every Tuesday by horse and wagon when roads were good and horse and sleigh in the winter months. He would stop at mailboxes along the way and also pick up and outgoing mail left in the box. In 1930 the delivery was changed from Tuesday and Wednesday to Thursday and Friday. Dick George and then George Bedard were the rural mailmen after Jim McCarten.

Louis Creek Post office Postmaster J.F. Smith 1894 - various other postmasters until Florence ran it from 1951-to 1965. The rural mail to Squam Bay on Wednesdays was delivered by Charlie Keller out of the Barriere PO. The first trips were by horse and democrat in summer and by sleigh in winter. When roads improved in 1927 Charlie bought a Model T for use in the summer. He delivered the mail for 25 years and then John Dennery took over until he retired in 1970. Then Rob Rutten operated the route. The post office burned during the forest fire of 2003.

Chinook Cove The first post office was established 1910 on the west side of the North Thompson river It closed in 1968. In 1937 residents towards the north of Chinook cove established a post office and was called the Darfield Post Office. The first postmistress was Sarah Robers, then Vera Underwood and Florence Beharrell.

Chu Chua In 1907 a post office was established in the Chu Chua store and George Fennell or his son, Marston, was in charge of its operation until closing in 1967. The stagecoach brought mail as far as Chu Chua and Ed Fortier delivered it to northern communities.

Little Fort In what is now Little Fort, the residents wanted a post office and petitioned the government. It was named Mt. Olie and the east side post office operated by Mrs. A. Genier for two years from 1907 to 1909. The new one opened in 1910 and postmasters were T. Latremouille, Kingscote, Wolsey, Gainer, Hindmarch, Miskelly Mrs. Steven and Mrs. Livingstone. Mrs. Livingston remained in this position for 35 years.

McLure The first post office in the area was established in 1914 and ran by Arthur Connine. It was the Fishtrap Post Office and was closed in 1926. The name McLure was formally established in 1919 when the ferry was put in place. The post office was part of the ferryman’s job, Vavenby In the community of Vavenby, the train station also served as the local post office, tending to the needs of the community, along with being the location of the only telephone for the area at the time, as it was situated in an addition to the house. In 1955 the post office was moved from the ferry house and Mrs. Christison became the postmaster All pictures and information have been taken from our history book, Exploring our Roots

urn:contentItem:6FSV-5F13-RV7M-J34K-00000-00Favourable winds, suppression efforts keep large forest fire away from northwestern Ontario First Nation2025-05-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisNATURAL DISASTERS NEWS & CANADA NEWSFavourable winds, suppression efforts keep large forest fire away from northwestern Ontario First Nation

Favourable winds and provincial firefighting efforts have led to the cancellation of a stage one evacuation for Wabaseemoong Independent Nations as a large forest fire burns nearby. 

The fire, known as Kenora 14, was discovered on Thursday 12 kilometres from Wabaseemoong. It has since grown to more than 1,000 hectares in size, and is not under control.

"We had another update meeting (Sunday) morning, and it looked promising that we won't have to do any evacuation," said Waylon Scott, chief of Wabaseemoong. "We were at the midst of doing a stage one evacuation, which is basically the vulnerable population."

Scott said the evacuation has now been put on hold.

Chris Marchand, fire information officer with Ontario's Aviation, Forest Fire and Emergency Services (AFFES), said southerly winds have kept the fire from advancing any closer to Wabaseemoong, and helped keep smoke out of the community.

As of Sunday, Marchand said, there were 11 fire ranger crews with several more on the way, and that they were focused on the southern and western areas of the fire closest to the community.

"They're getting some help from four helicopters, with an additional three aircraft on the way ... which will assist with bucketing and helping to move crews around, and equipment."

Scott said the community is relying on the province to keep the fire away from Wabaseemoong.

"The plan of attack that they have, it's looking favourable to the point where the fire most likely won't move towards the community," he said. "They're keeping the southern part of the fire at bay, and actually putting most of their resources on the southern part by bringing in a few more choppers to bucket the fire."

The province has also put travel restrictions in effect in the area of the fire. All travel and use of roads, including on Highway 525 beyond the northern boundary of Wabaseemoong, is prohibited without a permit.

Similarly, all use of lakes and waterways, and all use and occupation of Crown land, in the area is prohibited.

Wabaseemoong is located about 95 kilometres north of Kenora

Meanwhile, suppression efforts continue on Dryden 5, which is located near Peterson Cove on Sturgeon Lake, about 62 kilometres northeast of Ignace.

The fire is 140 hectares in size, and was not under control as of Sunday. Four crews are assigned to that fire, the province said.

urn:contentItem:6GGF-TGW3-RRR8-343P-00000-00Municipalities in Niagara Region issue fire bans as risk of fires 'extreme' in the region2025-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisMunicipalities in Niagara Region issue fire bans as risk of fires 'extreme' in the region

Several cities and towns in the Niagara Region have issued fire bans due to prolonged dry conditions.

The ban comes after Natural Resources Canada deemed parts of the region at "extreme" risk of fires.

Municipalities under the fire ban include:

In St. Catharines, the fire ban includes fireworks and sparklers as well as "any other types of outdoor burning." The city said on Monday those with agricultural burn permits are also banned from open fires.

"Those found burning under their permits will be charged and will have their permits revoked," said a news release.

The city also said those who don't comply with the ban could be fined up to $50,000.

"The open-air burning ban is in place to ensure the safety of all residents," said Dave Upper, chief of St. Catharines Fire Services. "There will be zero-tolerance and no warnings. The last thing we want to see here in St. Catharines is out-of-control fires like the ones currently burning across the country, including parts of Ontario."

Heat wave continues

Pelham fire chief Bob Lymburner said with current conditions, a fire can grow out of control "in no time."

"The burn ban is in place to protect everyone's safety."

Pelham, Niagara-on-the-Lake and West Lincoln also banned fireworks, with Pelham mentioning a ban on brush pile burns, recreational fires, burn barrels and outdoor fireplaces and chimneys, with the only exception being cooking fires in approved campgrounds.

The Niagara, Hamilton and surrounding areas are also under a heat warning until Wednesday.

According to the Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources, there are several active fires mostly in northeastern Ontario and firefighters in Kawartha Lakes have been battling a forest fire in the Burnt River area since Friday. According to Natural ResourcesCanada the Hamilton area is under high risk of fires.

Over 7.3 million hectares have burned in Canada so far in 2025, more than double the 10-year average for this time of year, according to the latest figures from the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre (CIFFC) and Natural ResourcesCanada. This would make this wildfire season the second worst on record nationally.

urn:contentItem:6G8B-1833-RSDJ-J113-00000-00Air quality alert issued for Toronto, GTA as forest fire smoke pushes levels to 'high risk'2025-07-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisTHESTAR/NEWS/ONTARIOPg. 1Air quality alert issued for Toronto, GTA as forest fire smoke pushes levels to 'high risk'Allie Moustakis

Toronto and much of the GTA are under a special air quality statement as smoke from forest fires in northern Ontario pushes into the region, Environment Canada warned Sunday night.

The agency says winds are carrying smoke into the area, reducing visibility and pushing the Air Quality Health Index to 10+, classified as "very high risk," early Monday morning. Poor air quality is expected to persist into Monday and possibly Tuesday, Environment Canada added.

Torontonians are urged to reduce or reschedule strenuous outdoor activities, particularly if you experience coughing, runny nose, throat or eye irritation or any other symptoms.

People aged 65 and older, pregnant people, infants and young children, people with an existing illness or chronic health condition and people who work outdoors are most at risk, Environment Canada says, adding that more serious symptoms such as chest pain or severe coughing should be treated as medical emergencies.

"Wildfire smoke isn't just haze - it's toxic," Toronto Public Health said, warning that the smoke is filled with pollution, carbon monoxide and other harmful chemicals.

The city adds that people should consider masking up while they're outside to reduce exposure.

Residents are encouraged to stay indoors, keep windows closed, use high-quality air filters or air purifiers and stay up to date on the air quality in their area.

If it comes down to choosing between avoiding smoky air or staying cool during an extreme heat event, the agency says people should prioritize keeping cool.

Toronto is still battling a heat warning Monday with temperatures expected to top out at 31 C, with a humidex of 40, according to Environment Canada.

The city says they have more than 500 cooling spaces around Toronto for anybody looking for relief. The heat wave has extended hours at the North York, Scarborough, Etobicoke, York and East York civic centres, with all of them now closing at 9:30 p.m. The Metro Hall lobby area is also open 24/7 during the heat wave.

Many city pools have extended their hours as well, staying open until 11:45 p.m., a spokesperson told the Star.

urn:contentItem:6G8B-1833-RSDJ-J0TN-00000-00Air quality alert issued for Toronto, GTA as forest fire smoke pushes levels to 'high risk'2025-07-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisTHESTAR/NEWS/ONTARIOPg. 1Air quality alert issued for Toronto, GTA as forest fire smoke pushes levels to 'high risk'Allie Moustakis

Toronto and much of the GTA are under a special air quality statement as smoke from forest fires in northern Ontario pushes into the region, Environment Canada warned Sunday night.

The agency says winds are carrying smoke into the area, reducing visibility and pushing the Air Quality Health Index to 10+, classified as "very high risk," early Monday morning. Poor air quality is expected to persist into Monday and possibly Tuesday, Environment Canada added.

Torontonians are urged to reduce or reschedule strenuous outdoor activities, particularly if you experience coughing, runny nose, throat or eye irritation or any other symptoms.

People aged 65 and older, pregnant people, infants and young children, people with an existing illness or chronic health condition and people who work outdoors are most at risk, Environment Canada says, adding that more serious symptoms such as chest pain or severe coughing should be treated as medical emergencies.

"Wildfire smoke isn't just haze - it's toxic," Toronto Public Health said, warning that the smoke is filled with pollution, carbon monoxide and other harmful chemicals.

The city adds that people should consider masking up while they're outside to reduce exposure.

Residents are encouraged to stay indoors, keep windows closed, use high-quality air filters or air purifiers and stay up to date on the air quality in their area.

If it comes down to choosing between avoiding smoky air or staying cool during an extreme heat event, the agency says people should prioritize keeping cool.

Toronto is still battling a heat warning Monday with temperatures expected to top out at 31 C, with a humidex of 40, according to Environment Canada.

The city says they have more than 500 cooling spaces around Toronto for anybody looking for relief. The heat wave has extended hours at the North York, Scarborough, Etobicoke, York and East York civic centres, with all of them now closing at 9:30 p.m. The Metro Hall lobby area is also open 24/7 during the heat wave.

Many city pools have extended their hours as well, staying open until 11:45 p.m., a spokesperson told the Star.

urn:contentItem:6GXT-K963-RS8D-F3VF-00000-00Manhunt ends south of Latchford, suspect in custody2025-10-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisSPARE NEWSManhunt ends south of Latchford, suspect in custodySue Nielsen, Local Journalism Initiative ReporterTemiskaming Speaker

Sue Nielsen

Local Journalism Initiative Reporter

LATCHFORD — A three-day manhunt ended south of Latchford near Roosevelt Road Sunday, October 5, at approximately 3:35 p.m., when police issued a press release stating one individual had been taken into custody.

Members of the Ontario Provincial Police (OPP) had been in pursuit of a 34-year-old male who was believed to be armed and dangerous. The police had issued a photograph of the suspect to the public online during the manhunt.

The situation began on the evening of Friday, October 3, when police responded to reports of an armed and dangerous individual at large in the area. An emergency alert and shelter in place order was issued by police stating an “individual armed with a long gun has entered a wooded area southeast of Latchford, Ont.”

Police then advised residents in the Latchford and Temagami North areas to shelter in place, lock all doors and windows if inside and stay clear of Roosevelt Road, which had remained closed all day Sunday during the intense manhunt.

Police told the public via social media and press releases that there was a heavy police presence in the area of Roosevelt Road. At the same time as the manhunt was developing Sunday, a forest fire erupted at the location near Straight Lake.

Special Investigations Unit (SIU) spokesperson Kristy Denette confirmed in an email message to The Speaker that the Roosevelt Road fire was related to the manhunt.

“Yes, the fire is connected to the incident,” she said.

Police had set up a command central location at the Latchford municipal office where more than 12 cars, trucks, a large crime unit van and an OPP boat were parked at various times during the search for the suspect.

The OPP Tactics and Rescue Unit, Emergency Response Unit, Canine Units and OPP Aviation experts were all on the scene of the manhunt at various times over the course of the three-day pursuit.

Temiskaming District EMS trucks and ambulances were also on site with a special ATV unit on the ready.

An OPP helicopter was seen circling the skies over Latchford, then landing at various times during the manhunt at Veteran's Park in Latchford.

On October 5, the helicopter was seen circling a location just northeast of Roosevelt Road along with police drone units. A police loudspeaker was heard calling for the suspect to give himself up and that he would not be hurt.

Police also asked the suspect to walk out of his location, come to the top of the train tracks with his hands in the air and he would not be harmed.

“If you can hear us come out to the top of the ridge so we can see you. We are here to help you. We know you are not trying to hurt us and we aren’t trying to hurt you. Come to the top of the train tracks,” said police through a loudspeaker.

Police had the suspect cornered just off a bush road. They said after a brief exchange of gunfire the suspect was apprehended and taken to hospital with non-life threatening injuries.

An OPP canine also received minor injuries in the apprehension.

Police had closed Highway 11 from Highway 65 in New Liskeard to Thibeault Hill at the north end of North Bay during the suspect’s apprehension on October 5.

SIU INVESTIGATION

Police issued a report after the wanted man was taken into custody stating that Highway 11 would be closed for an extended period of time.

Special Investigations Unit (SIU) officers were conducting an investigation in the area just south of Latchford where the manhunt had concluded.

Police had provided instructions on how to navigate around the closed highways via a route through Northwestern Quebec.

According to the OPP, the SIU has invoked its mandate and the OPP will not be able to provide further information.

urn:contentItem:6GH9-80S3-RSGF-C172-00000-00Critics of forest fire restrictions are painted as conspiracy theorists. This is why they might not be2025-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisOPINION/CONTRIBUTORSPg. 1Critics of forest fire restrictions are painted as conspiracy theorists. This is why they might not beJustin Ling

Nova Scotia is, if you listen to a small-but-loud chorus, sliding into "authoritarianism" and "totalitarianism." It is the testing ground for draconian "climate lockdowns" and a sign of a malignant government "paranoia." For most Nova Scotians, their government's decision to ban anyone from entering the woods for any reason, save on their own property - issued with the blunt warning of "STAY OUT OF THE WOODS" - is a necessary precaution to prevent forest fires amid a bone dry summer.But many others, mostly elsewhere in Canada, see this hiking-and-camping ban as something more sinister: that "it's deja vu."The backlash, like so many weird externalities today, is really about the pandemic. And it is a blinking indicator that, while many of us may be keen to move on from those wretched years, COVID-19 - and our governments' response to it - still looms large in the minds of many.

It has made them cynical and distrustful. But contrary to what many mainstream commentators say, maybe they're not wrong to feel that way.Earlier this week, army veteran Jeff Evely incurred a $28,872.50 fine for venturing into the woods in Cape Breton. It wasn't accidental: He walked up to a conversation officer and announced "I'm going to go in the woods over there."During the pandemic, Evely became convinced that our freedom and liberties were slipping away. He joined the anti-vaccine Freedom Convoy and ran for the conspiratorial People's Party. He believed the lockdowns and vaccine mandates were part of a larger plan to impose total government control, and he thinks his province's forest ban is a continuation of that plot.Evely may be an extreme example, but he's a citizen like the rest of us. And any citizen in a liberal democracy generally asks themselves two questions about state action in tough times: Do I trust my government to effectively manage this crisis? And do I trust that my government will behave responsibly with the power I surrender to it?We all have a point where the answer to those questions switches from yes to no. We can all agree that shelter-in-place orders during a mass shooting are reasonable, but that a citywide lockdown to find the mayor's missing cat would not be.This isn't just a perception problem. Think back to 2020: Canadians overwhelmingly heeded stay-at-home orders, understanding them as necessary. In the ensuing two years, however, compliance for heavy-handed measures declined precipitously.Governments showed their penchant for overreaction, just as the quality of their services were declining. We saw our leaders - some who are still in power - as incompetent and prone to overreaction. At the same time, they expected the public's faith to return, as though trust is some default position: It is not. Public relations firm Edelman conducts an annual "Trust Barometer." Between 2021 and this year, they observed a 21-point jump in the number of Canadians who worry that our leaders "purposely mislead people by saying things they know are false or gross exaggerations."This has huge public policy ramifications. When governments deliver instructions to their citizens in exceptional times - don't go outside, wear a mask, don't start fires, get vaccinated - success is measured by compliance. Compliance is a factor of trust.This is the second time Nova Scotia has had to resort to such a ban on its sprawling forests. The last time was just two years ago, as devastating wildfires ripped through the province. (Evely challenged it then, too. Unsuccessfully.) Nova Scotians, luckily, seem to be complying with the rules, although the province is still struggling to contain some fires across the province.The warnings of dystopia and autocracy emanating from elsewhere in the country, however, should cause some concern.A few months back, I was chatting with a former public health officer. I asked when we may finally see a public inquiry into how our governments responded to the pandemic. They gave a cynical laugh: "Never."Such a public inquiry is likely to tell us that, yes, governments did overreach when they imposed arbitrary lockdowns and curfews, and no the science did not support such measures. Doing so, of course, would provide ammunition to the conspiracy theorists - who are wrong about an awful lot, but right about a select few things. Hence why that former public health official believed it would never happen.We're entering into challenging times, and there are already so many malign pressures weakening trust in our institutions - sloppy faux-journalism on social media, outright misinformation, catchy conspiracy theories, amongst others. A public inquiry is a good mea culpa. But rebuilding trust, such that Canadians don't reflexively go toward suspicion when governments act, is going to be a long hard road.

urn:contentItem:6FMS-H063-RSMT-V518-00000-00New Jersey forest fire prompts thousands of evacuations and closes a major highway2025-04-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:41:53ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONALNew Jersey forest fire prompts thousands of evacuations and closes a major highwayThe Associated Press

BARNEGAT TOWNSHIP, N.J. (AP) — A fast-moving wildfire burning in New Jersey on Tuesday forced thousands of people to evacuate and closed a stretch of a major highway.

The Garden State Parkway, one of New Jersey's busiest highways, was closed between Barnegat and Lacey townships, according to the New Jersey Fire Service.

More than 1,300 structures were threatened and about 3,000 residents were evacuated, the fire service said. Shelters were open at two high schools, according to the Barnegat Police Department.

The Jersey Central Power and Light Company cut power to about 25,000 customers at the request of the Forest Fire Service and the wildfire’s command post Tuesday evening, including thousands in Barnegat Township. The company said on X that it doesn’t expect to restore the power before Wednesday.

“This is for the safety of crews battling the fire,” the company said.

The fire in the Greenwood Forest Wildlife Management Area burned more than 13.2 square miles (34.2 square kilometers) of land, fire officials said.

The blaze, burning in Ocean and Lacey Townships in Ocean County, was only about 10% contained Tuesday night, the New Jersey Fire Service said. The cause of the fire was under investigation.

There were no immediate reports of injuries.

Debi Schaffer was caught in gridlocked traffic after evacuating with her two dogs while her husband agreed to stay with their 22 chickens, The Press of Atlantic City reported.

“I wanted to take them in the car with me; can you imagine 22 chickens in a car?" she told the newspaper.

Around her Waretown house it was “like a war zone,” she said, describing smoke, sirens and the buzz of helicopters.

The site of the fire is near an alpaca farm. The farm said in a Facebook post that the property wasn’t threatened and all of the animals were safe.

The blaze is the second major forest fire in the region in less than a week.
